content.text: Determine the distance travelled by the cyclist between points C and E
distance travelled =   .........  m
Describe the motion, if any, of the cyclist between points B and C
State the section, AB, BC, CD or DE, of the graph in which the speed of the cyclist is the fastest. Give a reason for your answer
section of graph
reason
Calculate the average speed of the cyclist between points A and E. Include the unit in your answer
average speed =   .........  unit   .........
A cyclist travels to a friend's house
Fig. 1.1 shows the distance–time graph of the journey
A coin collector has 19 identical coins, as shown in Fig. 2.1
Fig. 2.2 shows one of the coins in the coin collector's hand
The coin collector wants to check the thickness of one coin. She has a \(30 \text{cm}\) ruler
Describe how she can use the \(30 \text{cm}\) ruler to determine the thickness of one coin accurately
You may include a diagram if you wish
Show that the density of this coin is about \(10 \text{g} /\text{cm}^3\)
The density of liquid mercury is \(13.6 \text{g} /\text{cm}^3\). State and explain whether the coin in **(b)**(i) floats on liquid mercury
The coin collector finds another coin. She thinks this coin is made of gold
She performs an experiment to find the coin's density
She obtains the following results:
mass of coin = 52.5g
volume of coin = \(5.4 \text{cm}^3\)
Calculate the size of the resultant vertical force on the rocket
resultant force =   .........  N
Explain why the top of the rocket is pointed and has a smooth surface
Fig. 3.1 shows the vertical forces acting on a toy rocket as it leaves the ground
To find the mass of the metal block, the teacher uses a ............................................
To measure the length, width and height of the metal block, she uses a ....................
A teacher wants to measure the mass of a block of metal. She also wants to measure the length, width and height of the block
Fig. 4.1 shows the block of metal
Complete each sentence using a word from the list
**balance** **barometer** **protractor** **ruler** **voltmeter**
The mass of the block is \(5000\mathrm{g}\)
Calculate the weight of the block
weight =   .........  N
Calculate the area of the block of metal in contact with the solid surface
The weight of the block of metal in Fig. 4.2 is \(60 \text{N}\)
Calculate the pressure of the block of metal on the solid surface
pressure =   .........  N/cm²
Fig. 4.2 shows another block of metal on a solid surface
A student determines the centre of mass of a piece of wood. The wood is an irregular shape of constant thickness
He suspends the piece of wood from a nail as shown in Fig. 5.1. The wood is able to swing freely
The student suspends a weight on a thin string from the nail
Describe how to determine the centre of mass of the piece of wood in Fig. 5.1
You may draw a diagram to help your answer
Fig. 5.2 shows a flat, symmetrical object. Indicate its centre of mass by drawing X in the correct position
Fig. 5.3 shows a side view of a drinking-glass in two different positions, A and B
State which position, A or B, is more stable. Explain your answer
A girl has eight objects made of different materials
The materials have different electrical and magnetic properties
a piece of copper wire a sheet of aluminium foil a glass rod an iron nail
a piece of cotton cloth a wooden block a plastic strip a paper bag
Complete Table 6.1 by adding **one** object for each property. One is done for you
Choose objects from the list. Each object may be used once, more than once or not at all

table.html:
propertyobject
electrical conductor
electrical insulator
non-magnetic materiala wooden block
magnetic material
can be charged by rubbing with a cloth

content.text: Fig. 6.1 shows three measuring instruments
Write the name of each measuring instrument next to its diagram
The measuring instruments are **not** drawn to scale
Fig. 7.1 shows a candle underneath a thin, metal fan
When the candle starts to burn, the fan starts to rotate around its support
Explain what causes the fan to rotate
Draw the bimetallic strip when the temperature is \(10^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\)
The bimetallic strip is used in a circuit, as shown in Fig. 7.4. The circuit is in a room
The room temperature is \(25^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\)
State and explain any changes in the circuit as the temperature of the room rises above \(40^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\)
Fig. 7.2 shows a bimetallic strip. It is made of two metals, steel and copper, fastened together
The bimetallic strip is straight when the temperature is \(25^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\)
Fig. 7.3 shows the bimetallic strip when the temperature is \(40^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\)
State the energy source for a geothermal power station. ............................................
Complete the sentence about useful energy transfer in the power station
State two advantages of a geothermal power station compared to a coal-fired power station
State one disadvantage of using geothermal energy rather than coal in a power station
Fig. 8.1 shows a simplified diagram of a geothermal power station
State which angle, \(a\), \(b\), \(c\) or \(d\), is the angle of incidence. .......................................
State which angle, \(a\), \(b\), \(c\) or \(d\), is the angle of reflection. .........................................
Fig. 9.1 shows a ray of light reflected by a plane mirror
Fig. 9.2 shows a road junction viewed from above. A plane mirror allows the drivers of the two cars A and B to see each other
Fig. 9.2 shows a ray of light from car A travelling towards the plane mirror
On Fig. 9.2, carefully continue this ray to show how the driver of car B can see car A
State the physical quantity that an ammeter measures
Indicate the correct statement about the readings \(A_{1}, A_{2}\) and \(A_{3}\) on the ammeters in Fig. 10.1
Tick one box

table.html:
\(A_{2}\) is greater than \(A_{1}\)
\(A_{2}\) is less than \(A_{3}\)
\(A_{1}\) is equal to \(A_{3}\)
\(A_{1}\) is equal to \((A_{2} + A_{3})\)

content.text: Fig. 10.1 shows two resistors connected in series with a cell and three ammeters
Draw a circuit diagram for a battery connected to two resistors in parallel
State one advantage of connecting lamps in parallel
Name component X in Fig. 10.2
Suggest one use of the circuit
Describe how to use component X and explain its effect on the circuit
Fig. 10.2 shows another circuit
The circuit consists of a power supply, a lamp and component X
Fig. 11.1 shows a magnet and a coil of wire connected to a galvanometer
A student slowly moves the magnet into the coil. The pointer on the galvanometer moves to the left. This deflection shows that an electromotive force (e.m.f.) is induced in the coil
State **three** ways of increasing the size of the e.m.f. in the coil
Name **one** material that is suitable for the core of the transformer
The primary coil has 1000 turns and its input is 240V a.c
The secondary coil has 50 turns
Calculate the output voltage across the secondary coil
output voltage =   .........  V
Fig. 11.2 shows a transformer
State which radioactive emission is:
Explain the meaning of the term isotope
The isotope iodine-131 is used in hospitals. A sample of iodine-131 is prepared for use
The half-life of iodine-131 is 8 days
Determine the fraction of iodine-131 remaining in the sample after 16 days
fraction remaining =   .........
